content:
I think I messed up with the PR process. I intended to to make many PRs containing small, self-contained pieces, so I committed+pushed some material and created this PR. Later I committed material intended for a 2nd PR (to be reviewed afterwards) but it got absorbed by this one.

Should I rebase my branch in order to eliminate that last commit?

Apart from some line overflows, I think it looks OK, but if I keep it, the commit message for the PR has half the information right now.
We don't care about the commit history within a PR because we squash-merge, so do whatever you prefer!
We do actually have a policy not to rebase / force push to make reviewers' life easier

Ruben Van de Velde said:

We do actually have a policy not to rebase / force push to make reviewers' life easier

I understand that, when the review process has started. I'll just commit to satisfy the linters then.

EDIT: Well, I did that and edited the PR title & comment in order to better reflect the current situation. I also explained that the changes to set_theory could be reviewed separately (that was my original intent).

On the new file borel_hierarchy.lean: Near the end, the main results in measure_theory.card_measurable_space are reproved. As part of the initial development, I removed the original (theorem) docstrings.
I believe it would be reasonable to split the file, use the last part as a replacement of measure_theory.card_measurable_space while adding the missing theorem docstrings and the original authors to the list.
